case_name: Directors and Officer of Rajnagar Spinning and Weaving Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Inspector under the Employees Provident Funds Act

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 57 of 1973 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal, No. 57 of 1973. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 9th February 1973 of Gujarat High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 86 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 9th February 1973 of the Gujarat High Court at Ahmedabad in Criminal Revision Application No. 86 of 1973.

facts.text: Appellants 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6 are directors of Rajnagar Spinning and Weaving Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6 are the directors of Rajnagar Spinning and Weaving Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Ahmedabad, and appellant No. 3 is an officer of the said companypany.

facts.text: Appellant No. 3 is an officer of Rajnagar Spinning and Weaving Manufacturing Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: , and appellant No. 3 is an officer of the said companypany. On March 19, 1969 a companyplaint was lodged against them by respondent 1, an Inspector appointed under the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952

facts.text: On March 19, 1969, complaint lodged against appellants by respondent 1, Inspector under Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1969 a companyplaint was lodged against them by respondent 1, an Inspector appointed under the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952 that they bad failed to pay a sum of Rs. 1,39,419 .50

facts.text: Appellants failed to pay Rs. 1,39,419.50 being company's contribution to Provident Fund for June, July and August 1968.

anchor.surface_text: that they bad failed to pay a sum of Rs. 1,39,419 .50 being the companytribution to the Provident Fund for the months of June, July and August. 1968 and that thereby they had companytravened

facts.text: Appellants contravened Paragraph 38(1) of Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 1968 and that thereby they had companytravened the provisions of Paragraph 38 1  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme. 1952, an act punishable under Paragraph 76 a  of the Scheme.

facts.text: Contravention punishable under Paragraph 76(a) of the Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: 1952, an act punishable under Paragraph 76 a  of the Scheme. An investigation was made into the affairs of the companypany under section 15 of the Industries  Development and Regulation  Act, 1951

facts.text: Investigation made into affairs of company under section 15 of Industries Development and Regulation Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: An investigation was made into the affairs of the companypany under section 15 of the Industries  Development and Regulation  Act, 1951 and on being satisfied that the companypany was managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest,

facts.text: Government of India satisfied company managed in manner highly detrimental to public interest.

anchor.surface_text: and on being satisfied that the companypany was managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest, the Government of India issued an order dated January 7, 1972 authorising the Gujarat State Textile Corporation

facts.text: Government of India issued order dated January 7, 1972 authorizing Gujarat State Textile Corporation to take over management of company.

anchor.surface_text: the Government of India issued an order dated January 7, 1972 authorising the Gujarat State Textile Corporation to take over the management of the companypany. On May 69 1972 the Gujarat Government issued a numberification declaring

facts.text: On May 6, 1972, Gujarat Government issued notification declaring company a relief undertaking under section 4(1)(a)(iv) of Bombay Relief Undertakings Special Provisions Act, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On May 69 1972 the Gujarat Government issued a numberification declaring the companypany to be a relief undertaking under section 4 1  a  iv  of the Bombay Relief Undertakings  Special Provisions  Act, 1958  the Act , and directing that all rights,

facts.text: Notification directed suspension of rights, privileges, obligations, liabilities accrued before declaration, and stay of proceedings from 6th May 1972.

anchor.surface_text: and directing that all rights, privileges, obligations and liabilities accrued or incurred before the undertaking was declared a relief undertaking and any remedy for the enforcement thereof shall be suspended and all the proceedings relative thereto pending before any Court,

facts.text: Appellants filed applications to City Magistrate to stay prosecution in view of notification.

anchor.surface_text: tribunal, officer or authority shall be stayed with effect from 6th May 1972 The appellants filed one application after another asking the companyrt which was seized of the matter to stay the prosecution in view of the numberification

facts.text: Two applications rejected by City Magistrate, III Court, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: issued by the Government of Gujarat. Two of such applications were rejected by the learned City Magistrate, III Court, Ahmeda- bad. Appellants acquiesced in one of the orders,

facts.text: Appellants acquiesced in one rejection order, filed revision in High Court for other but withdrew it.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants acquiesced in one of the orders, carried the other in revision to the High Court but withdrew that proceeding. on October 27, 1972 they made yet another application

facts.text: On October 27, 1972, appellants made another application for stay, rejected by Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: on October 27, 1972 they made yet another application for the same relief which also was rejected by the learned Magistrate. He took the view, as in the two earlier applications,

facts.text: Magistrate held section 4 of Act restricted to statutes in Schedule, clause (iv) does not contemplate stay of criminal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: that the operation of section 4 of the Act is restricted to the statutes mentioned in the Schedule to that Act and that clause  iv  of section 4 1  did number companyplete stay of criminal proceedings.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court rejected summarily the revision application against Magistrate's judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Gujarat rejected summarily the revision application filed by the appellants against the judgment of the learned Magistrate. This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal concerns whether prosecution under Para 76(a) EPF Scheme is stayed by notification of May 6, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with the narrow question whether the prosecution pending against the appellants under Paragraph 76 a  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 is liable to be stayed by virtue of the numberification issued

facts.text: Notification issued under section 4(1)(a)(iv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: by the Government of Gujarat on May 6, 1972. That numberification was issued in exercise of the power companyferred by section 4 1  a  iv  of the Act, which reads thus 4.  1  Notwithstanding any law, usage, custom, companytract,

facts.text: Court held sub-clause (iv) concerns pre-existing obligations and liabilities of the undertaking, not directors personally.

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability which sub-clause  iv  speaks of is an obligation or liability incurred by the undertaking before it was declared a relief undertaking. In other words sub-clause  iv  companycerns itself with the pre-existing obligations and liabilities of the undertaking and number of its directors managers or other officers,

facts.text: Obligations of directors are personal, not in relation to relief undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability of these persons is number companyprehended within the words of sub-clause  iv . Clause  a  of section 4 1  shows that the power of the State Government is itself restricted to giving directions referred to in sub-clause  iv , in relation to any relief undertaking.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeal, directs prosecution to proceed expeditiously.

anchor.surface_text: Such a personal liability does number fall within the scope of section 4 1  a  iv  of the Act. We therefore dismiss the appeal and direct that the prosecution shall proceed expeditiously.

issues.text: whether the prosecution pending against the appellants under Paragraph 76 a of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 is liable to be stayed by virtue of the numberification issued by the Government of Gujarat on May 6, 1972

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with the narrow question whether the prosecution pending against the appellants under Paragraph 76 a  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 is liable to be stayed

issues.text: whether the obligation or liability which sub-clause (iv) of section 4(1)(a) speaks of includes obligations or liabilities of directors, managers or other officers of the undertaking

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability which sub-clause  iv  speaks of is an obligation or liability incurred by the undertaking before it was declared a relief undertaking. In other words sub-clause  iv  companycerns

arguments.claim: Prosecution pending against appellants under Paragraph 76(a) of Employees Provident Funds Scheme is liable to be stayed by notification under section 4(1)(a)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned in this appeal with the narrow question whether the prosecution pending against the appellants under Paragraph 76 a  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 is liable to be stayed by virtue of the notification issued

court_response_anchor.surface_text: undertaking as a relief undertaking, as a measure of preventing unemployment or of unemployment relief. Relief undertakings, so long as they companyti

arguments.court_reasoning: Provision applies only to pre-existing obligations and liabilities of the undertaking itself, not personal liabilities of directors and officers

arguments.claim: Operation of section 4 of the Act is restricted to statutes mentioned in the Schedule to that Act

anchor.surface_text: that the operation of section 4 of the Act is restricted to the statutes mentioned in the Schedule to that Act and that clause  iv  of section 4 1  did

arguments.claim: Clause (iv) of section 4(1) does not contemplate stay of criminal proceedings

anchor.surface_text: and that clause  iv  of section 4 1  did not contemplate stay of criminal proceedings. The High Court of Gujarat rejected summarily the revision application filed

court_response_anchor.surface_text: undertaking as a relief undertaking, as a measure of preventing unemployment or of unemployment relief. Relief undertakings, so long as they companyti

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed no stay, but on ground of personal liability rather than criminal nature

arguments.claim: Obligation or liability in sub-clause (iv) is incurred by the undertaking, concerns pre-existing obligations of undertaking not directors managers or officers

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability which sub-clause  iv  speaks of is an obligation or liability incurred by the undertaking before it was declared a relief undertaking. In other words sub-clause  iv  concerns itself with the pre-existing obligations and liabilities of the undertaking and not of its directors managers or other officers,

arguments.claim: Obligation or liability of directors and officers not comprehended within words of sub-clause (iv)

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability of these persons is not comprehended within the words of sub-clause  iv . Clause  a  of section 4 1  shows that the power of the State Government is itself restricted to giving directions referred to in sub-clause  iv , in relation to any relief undertaking.

arguments.claim: Obligations and liabilities of directors or officers not in true sense obligations in relation to relief undertaking but personal

anchor.surface_text: Obligations and liabilities of the directors or other officers of the undertaking are not in a true sense obligations and liabilities in relation to the relief undertaking. In plain and simple language they are, the obligations and liabilities of such persons themselves.

arguments.claim: Object of section 4(1)(a)(iv) is moratorium on actions against the undertaking during notification period

anchor.surface_text: The object of section 4 1  a  iv  is to declare, so to say, a moratorium on actions against the undertaking during the currency of the notification declaring it to be a relief undertaking. By sub-clause  iv , any remedy for the enforcement of an obligation or liability against the relief undertaking is suspended

arguments.claim: Provisions aimed at resurrecting mismanaged undertakings to prevent unemployment of workers

anchor.surface_text: Under section 4 b , on the notification ceasing to have force, such obligations and liabilities revive and become enforceable and the proceedings which are stayed can be continued. These provisions are aimed at resurrecting and rehabilitating industrial undertakings brought by inefficiency or mismanagement to the brink of dissolution, posing thereby the grave threat of unemployment of industrial workers.

arguments.claim: Relief undertakings given immunity from legal actions for smooth working and unemployment relief

anchor.surface_text: Relief undertaking means under section 2  g  an industrial undertaking in respect of which a declaration under section 3 is in force. By section 3, power is conferred on the State Government to declare an industrial undertaking as a relief undertaking, as a measure of preventing unemployment or of unemployment relief.

arguments.claim: Neither language nor object justifies extending immunity to individual obligations of directors and officers

anchor.surface_text: Thus neither the language of the statute nor its object would justify the extension of the immunity so as to cover the individual obligations and liabilities of the directors and other officers of the undertaking.

arguments.claim: Extending stay to directors would benefit persons responsible for mismanagement necessitating notification

anchor.surface_text: If they have incurred such obligations or liabilities, as distinct from the obligations or liabilities of the undertaking, they are liable to be proceeded against for their personal acts of commission and omission. ... To declare a moratorium on legal actions against persons whose activities have necessitated the issuance of a notification in the interest of unemployment relief is to give to such persons the benefit of their own wrong.

arguments.claim: Paragraph 38(1) imposes obligation on employer to pay PF contribution within 15 days; employer includes directors with ultimate control per s.2(e)(ii) EPF Act

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 38 1  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 imposes an obligation on the employer to pay the Provident Fund contribution to the Fund within 15 days of the close of every month. The Scheme does not define Employer but Paragraph 2 m  says that words and expressions which are not defined by the Scheme shall have the meaning assigned to them in the Employees Provident Funds Act. Section 2 e  ii  of that Act defines an Employer,

arguments.claim: Appellants liable under Paragraph 76(a) for personal failure to pay contributions; such personal liability not within section 4(1)(a)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: Thus the responsibility to pay the contributions to the Fund was of the appellants and if they have defaulted in paying the amount, they are liable to be prosecuted under Paragraph 76 a  of the Scheme which says that if any person fails to pay any contribution which he is liable to pay under the Scheme, he shall be punishable with six months imprisonment or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees or with both. Such a personal liability does not fall within the scope of section 4 1  a  iv  of the Act.

holdings.text: The prosecution pending against the appellants under Paragraph 76(a) of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 is not liable to be stayed by virtue of the notification issued under section 4(1)(a)(iv) of the Bombay Relief Undertakings (Special Provisions) Act, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with the narrow question whether the prosecution pending against the appellants under Paragraph 76 a  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 is liable to be stayed by virtue of the numberification issued

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal liability of directors under EPF Scheme para 76(a) not covered by s.4(1)(a)(iv) which suspends only pre-existing obligations/liabilities of the undertaking itself; supported by textual reading, purpose of moratorium for undertaking rehabilitation, and policy against shielding mismanagers.

holdings.text: Sub-clause (iv) of section 4(1)(a) concerns pre-existing obligations and liabilities incurred by the relief undertaking itself, and not those of its directors, managers or other officers.

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability which sub-clause  iv  speaks of is an obligation or liability incurred by the undertaking before it was declared a relief undertaking. In other words sub-clause  iv  companycerns itself with the pre-existing obligations and liabilities of the undertaking and number of its directors managers or other officers,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of sub-clause (iv) refers to obligations/liabilities 'incurred by the undertaking'; clause (a) restricts directions to those 'in relation to any relief undertaking'.

holdings.text: Obligations and liabilities of directors or other officers are personal and not in relation to the relief undertaking, hence not comprehended within sub-clause (iv) of section 4(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The obligation or liability of these persons is number companyprehended within the words of sub-clause  iv . Clause  a  of section 4 1  shows that the power of the State Government is itself restricted to giving directions referred to in sub-clause  iv , in relation to any relief undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directors' obligations viewed separately from impersonal company obligations; power under s.4(1)(a) limited to relief undertaking.

holdings.text: Directors and officers with ultimate control are 'employers' personally liable under Paragraph 38(1) and punishable under Paragraph 76(a) of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 for failure to pay Provident Fund contributions.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 38 1  of the Employees Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 imposes an obligation on the employer to pay the Provident Fund contribution to the Fund within 15 days of the close of every month. The Scheme does number define Employer but Paragraph 2 m  says that words and expressions which are number defined by the Scheme shall have the meaning assigned to them in the Employees Provident Funds Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 38(1) obligation on employer; Scheme adopts EPF Act s.2(e)(ii) definition including persons with ultimate control or managing directors; appellants had such responsibility and defaulted.

holdings.text: The object of section 4(1)(a)(iv) is to provide a moratorium on enforcement actions against the relief undertaking during the notification period to facilitate its rehabilitation and prevent unemployment.

anchor.surface_text: The object of section 4 1  a  iv  is to declare, so to say, a moratorium on actions against the undertaking during the currency of the. numberification declaring it to be a relief undertaking. By sub-clause  iv , any remedy for the enforcement of an obligation or liability against the relief undertaking is suspended

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions aim at resurrecting mismanaged undertakings per ss.2(g), 3, 4(b); immunity for smooth working as unemployment relief measure.

Section 4(1)(a)(iv) Bombay Relief Undertakings (Special Provisions) Act, 1958 support
Section 4(1)(a)(iv) Bombay Relief Undertakings (Special Provisions) Act, 1958 support

anchor.surface_text: We therefore dismiss the appeal and direct that the prosecution shall proceed expeditiously.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; prosecution directed to proceed expeditiously
